description.text: After looking around, i was not able to find a GoPro mount that i could use on my Vanguard tripod the Abeo Series, with a quick release so I mocked one up and it works flawlessly. Let me know if you there's anything wrong with it or any changes required that could either improve the design or make it easier to print. i printed it after slicing with simplify3d and adding supports on the underneath at 7mm wide.

This is an updated BB-8 body for EZ-Robot. It includes a rectangle slot for cables and a thinner shell for improved printing.

While the BB-8 head is pictured to show what it would look like on the body, it is not included in with these files. You can obtain from the above link.

If you need any standard EZ-Robot parts you can obtain them from http://www.ez-robot.com

title: Printrboard Mount w/ 80mm x 80mm x 25mm fan

description.text:
I bought a Geeeteck Printrboard clone which didn't have holes for mounting, so I designed a mount for it that doesn't use screws to hold the board in place.
I kinda took the idea from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:134882, but I designed it from scratch in Solidworks.
I included the Solidworks files incase anyone wants to change or modify this.

Print.
Assemble.
Attach to printer.
Print some more!

remixed_from.author: timmytool
remixed_from.title: Parametric Boltless Hook for keyhole shelving units

description.text:
I combined the ancestor hook idea with the self threading bolt idea from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15322
This allows the hook to lay flat for easy printing. I also added some curves for strength and aesthetics.
The hole is .125", so a 6-32 machine screw will self thread when screwed in.
2 screws required per hook.
You will need to make sure the hole spacing fits your application.
Print it, install the screws.
My wife needed a way to store the knitting markers I made for her, so here it is. Should work for various small things. Pillbox perhaps?
customized with 3D Slash!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

I bought my OnePlus One used, and it was missing it's SIM slot tray. I ordered a new one, and then I decided to design from photos and 3D Print it.

I couldn't actually 3D print it reliably, maybe is my cheap printer, or something.
But anybody else interested could try.

I provide the stl and the sketch up file for easier editing.

The files are provided "as is" and with no guarantee that they will work, you are free to modify them.
I am not reliable if something goes wrong and you damage your Phone, use at your own risk.

comments.text: Is this a micro, nano, or full sized sim tray?
comments.author: omfgtora

comments.text: It is designed to work with micro sim. Mini sim or full size sim won't work. Nano should work with an adapter.
comments.author: omfgtora

comments.text: Thanks!

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/eZBC0UMAokX This was inspired by "Hanging spiral" by RandomPretender on Thingiverse, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:154956. I put a bit of a basket in the center where LEDs will be mounted. The tape sticks down to the bottom and the baffles prevent the light from glaring. Hole in the top allows the electrical to be brought in.
I need to adjust my printer, there is severe curling so I had to cut short the build. But the pictures will show you the possibilities

I remixed thing 154956 by RandomPretender as stated above. The electrical supply (12V) can be run down the center joint, there are two holes in each "basket" to allow supply to the LED tape in each basket. The tape I used is available from DX.com and is 8mm wide with 60 LEDs / meter. Just a piece of 5cm long will be put in each basket, lighting up the slat above it and as the walls are thin enough some light will filter through as well. I will post some pictures as soon as I have it built.

comments.text: This looks really neat! Looking forward to some pics of it in action.
comments.author: RandomPretender

description.text: Lol

Full credit to Typhlosaurus (http://www.thingiverse.com/Typhlosaurus) who made his coffin design and inspired me to make this derivative! Use this little box to keep your favourite minifig in your pocket (if you are 5, or 35yrs old it doesn't matter!) The lid snaps tight and add a piece of string between the loops. I added these loops so I wouldn't be constantly searching for lost lids:) I added pegs to keep the minifig in place for display purposes. Thinking of adding sword and weapon holders inside later.
Print in your desired colour. I uses 20% fill with 1 shell. Enjoy!

author: Sidmo55

description.text:
Simple female torso I made myself.

It is about 7cm tall, but I am in the process of making a bigger one. I will upload it when I have tested it.

Used a lot of tools

Basic body came from Poser, changed a few things in IronCAD, used Meshmixer (for the first time) to remove all that I did not want and save it as a solid.
Then used transparent nGen to print it out. First model with infil, next an empty shell.

Both times I had just printed something in blue, that is why the legs have a blue tint.

comments.text: Did you ever make any progress on creating a higher resolution version of a nude female torso?

Paste extruder based on the Moineau pump principle. The pump geometry is based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7958 Should work as a plug-in replacement for a hot plastic extruder in a 3D printer. However, I have NOT used this to actually print anything. I'm just publishing it in case someone else wants to try it out. (I think it's ready for printing a very small pizza without toppings, but beyond that I cannot say.) Almost everything is parametrized and adjustable from the SCAD file. However, the resulting design should be evaluated to see if it is still sane after adjustment, since not all of the features are automatically calculated. Particularly the flange and driveshaft diameters must be adjusted by hand to match the other measurements. See it in action: http://youtu.be/OHQiKuQvuEU Note: obviously it is impossible to build an object from material that flows on it's own - the object would not hold it's shape. So in practice the material has to either be pulled into the extruder by a negative pressure (impossible with PLA printed pump parts) or pushed into the extruder by a positive pressure. In either case the motor axle has to be sealed, or it would either relieve the negative pressure or allow the material to flow up and out from the inlet block.

Print plastic parts. Cut flange seals from thin rubber (I used bicycle inner tube). Assemble with M3 nuts and bolts, adding a NEMA17 stepper motor. Fill inlet tube with material to be extruded and start the stepper motor.
There is a seal retention ring near the motor mount inside the inlet block, so that the motor shaft can be sealed with some kind of a seal. With this done, the inlet tube may be made thinner and a flexible tube connected to it for feeding the extruder from an external pressurized reservoir. (This part is still work in progress.)

description.text:
This is 3D model for a vase that would make use of recycled water bottles (600 ml size) as a container for the water and the flowers in this vase.

The deign is made in a way that the bottom is wide enough to get the bottle through the vase, while the top of the vase will act like a cap for the bottle, it will be turned until they are completely coupled. You could fill the bottle with water and use it as a beautiful vase.

The final design of the vase has some lotus flower combinations as shown. Uploaded are some screenshots for the design from different angles, I uploaded the plain body of the vase for any new compositions you may like, also I uploaded another modern abstract-shaped design for those who may love modern art, and finally I uploaded the final part of the inner cap for any testing you may like to do.

Unfortunately I hadn't printed this model so far for it's extremely high cost, so please if you printed it update me with some images and comments.

P.S. This is design is dedicated to "Aya Hassan Gaber" for her blissfulness, Kindness and her tireless efforts for making people around her happy.

title: Hoopadoop back to school set by LeHof

description.text: Free period getting you down? Gotta keep moving to stay awake? Play a round of basketball or netball right on your desk. This kit includes a pencil case with BB key. Ruler (which is actually a sneaky slingshot), and some pencil toppers. One is of a netball hoop, and the other is a basketball hoop for those that need a backboard to make their shots count ;)

Ok, so I've spent the last few weeks designing this pencil case, pencil toppers and ruler for the back to school challenge (#backtoschool). It should work equally well for ABS and PLA as I have used tollerances that will allow for some minor warping during printing for those that don't have great calibration.  
Add a rubber band and the ruler doubles as a mean slingshot for shooting hoops angry birds style. Both metric (centimeters) and imperial (inches) are shown on the ruler.  Slingshot ruler 2, is pretty much the same, but has a chamfer on the edges to make it a bit easier to rule lines.  
Two pencil toppers are included. One with a backboard and one netball style hoop to add more of a challenge. Place the pencil in the hole provided and you have your hoop set up ready to play. I have made these holes slightly oversized with a taper down to size so that you should be able to fit multiple diameters of pens/pencils. Jam in some bluetack if you have a smaller diameter pencil.  
The case can be opened up to catch the projectiles. Or left closed to keep those pesky bits of paper, crayons, erasor chucks from getting mixed in with your stuff.  
You can print the box, lid, and pencil topper 2 without any support. The ruler might require minimal support around the rubber band lugs (but will probably print ok without it).

description.text: protect your transponder (ilaps)

Update: This model now has a smoother deck and wheels with a bit more flair. This is an easy, fun and satisfying project to design and print that's well suited for students new to 3D modeling. Following along with this Inventor Studios Tinkercad tutorial when designing the board and this one when designing the wheels. Follow the entire collection to develop and refine your modeling skills. "Japanese Erasers" have been very popular with kids for several years, as have keychains that hang in bunches on the outside of backpacks. I find both, though the erasers in particular, to be excellent 3D learning tools. When taken apart they're reduced to basic 3D shapes that can be modeled on the computer then reconstructed as 3D printed objects, which are wonderful keepsakes of their class. I consider joinery to be an important early skill for young inventors to develop. So the most interesting designs in my class are those that consist of multiple pieces that are interesting whether together or as a pile of printed parts. The creation of this simple object, together with others that I've uploaded to Thingiverse, are useful exercises for anybody learning 3D modeling.

I printed in ABS on a Makerbot clone with an extruder temperature of 220 degrees, HBP at 100 degrees, and 0.2 resolution.
I use about 35 mm of filament for the axel. Once the wheels and deck are threaded I melt the ends using the hot-end of the extruder to create filament blobs so that the wheels stay on.

A sphere that you can modify to be a bowl, a ring, a bracelet, a wheel, a decorative lantern with LEDs inside.
Several tools provided, with very few limitations. It is probably easier to make a mistake rather than print what you want, so be careful.
Make the sphere, hollow it out, slice off the top and bottom, add a base. If you make a solid object like a wheel, you might want to control the axle diameter, otherwise leave it at zero.

Perhaps I am doing something wrong?

title: Prime pillar for dual extrusion prints

description.text:
This simple part can be used as a prime pillar for dual extrusion prints.
Place a copy of this pillar on either side of the part in your favorite slicing program. Scale the pillar in Z-direction to match the height of your part. The pillar is 10mm high to make scaling easy. For example, if your part is 25mm high, scale the pillar in Z-direction 250%.

The pillars will be printed together with the part and make sure the extruders are wiped and kept primed at each layer.

Make sure to place the pillars at least at a distance from the part that is greater than the distance between the nozzles, otherwise the nozzles will wipe clean on the edge of the part.

Visit my blog Uptimefab.com for a more detailed description on the use of the pillars.

http://uptimefab.com/2016/05/10/slic3r-settings-for-dual-extrusion-prints-on-flashforge-dreamer/

The sample part in the picture is a dice model From thingiverse, part no. 21842

author: Frickelpiet

description.text: Unfortunately, while I have moved in to the realm of SMD components, my old eyes continue to fail to keep up with my hobby.  I found a cheap (<$25) microscope on eBay that had a reasonable focal length that looked like it could really help me inspect and possibly solder these tiny SMD components.  Unfortunately, it came with a cheesy little stand that just wouldn't work at all for what I needed it for.  With my trusty 3D printer, some 8mm drill rods and linear bearings left over from building my printer, I was able to make a pretty good stand with decent height and a movable platform to hold the PCB.  Since moving the microscope around was a pain and caused me to refocus it at every move, I found that a platform that will hold the board and allow me to pan around the board is really handy.  Note I have the microscope at a slight angle to reduce the glare from the built in LEDs.  I have uploaded all of the parts for you to use and improve.  enjoy!

I will work on clear instructions if anyone requests them (Yes, I am a bit lazy).  Note that the PCB platform itself is laser cut acrylic, these are the included PLT and PWJ5 files from LaserCAD 6.27 (The software for the DSP controller I installed in my China laser cutter).  I will work on a DXF for this part.  I can provide a complete BOM upon request.

title: JD MM2 RAMPS fan mount plate for MendelMax 2

description.text:
This plate allows blowing direct jet of air on the X, Y and extruder stepper driver chips on a RAMPS board. I was most concerned about the Y axis driver as that has been causing me the most trouble. The Z driver gets residual air flow, which is more than enough for its work load.  
There is a pass-through hole for Z driver current adjustment, the other drivers could be handled by stopping the fan and passing a slender screwdriver between its blades.  
I designed this for my particular RAMPS controller setup, see the photo for how I located it.  This plate might work well with many other RepRap controller boards. You may need to adjust the controller board location, or adjust the drawing to relocate the fan as desired.

I used an engraving laser to cut 3mm / 1/8" thick acrylic. Any laser cuttable or routerable material should be fine, as long as it's not too thick. Drill & tap the plate to 3mm thread to mount a 40x40x10mm fan to the top or bottom side of the plate.  
The plate mounting holes will accept up to 5mm hardware, I used standard 4mm screws and some quick t-nuts from Adafruit for easy and quick access to the controller  
Use a 24VDC fan if it's a typical MendelMax 2.  
Make sure the fan will clear the Y table arms the full length of its travel!

Snap together body with locking clips- no pins or tools required Locks to common screws/nails or printed lanyard attachment Takes rope/cord/twine/string up to 4mm diameter, up to 5kg load Assembly & demonstration video: http://youtu.be/wRV7vyy9RSM
See MOKO Mini Pulley for matching attachments & more!

description.text:
Designed as a companion for the Adhesive Tape Dispenser the Memo Cube Holder shows the same strong grain of the birch plywood. I created it using a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs

Be aware that the 3-D file (obj) is for viewing only. It's not to be printed.

I started out with this rouch sketch (on the back of some choir sheet music) then I used Solid Edge 2D drafting to create the design and nested the parts pretty effective.. After gluing a little sanding was needed. To get a nice finish I used hard wax oil.

title: OpenForge 2.0 Cut Stone External Arched Door

description.text:
OpenForge 2.0

Building this set, I realized a new strength of the external tile set over the former edge tiles. The 0.5 versions of the tile can be glued separately from other parts on the cut stone base. I've included some examples of how you can use this to make doorways for halls, but I expect this approach in the future will make external tiles super flexible for building all kinds of tile combinations. Want a corner with a door on one side and a window on the other? This approach means we can do that.

I've included below some examples of me using this technique. You can also of course print the door tiles in a full range of sizes like normal. Don't forget that if you want to have the door open the other direction, just print it mirrored on the x axis.

Also I noticed when I had this setting next to each other in my painting station before I added doors, lining these up next to each other with no door makes for a fairly nice colonnade.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

Instructions

For assembly instructions, painting videos and other extra information, see the instructions on the cut-stone wall.

Making a cut-stone 1 door corridor

To assemble a corridor with a single door, print:

  • A 2x2 cut stone external corridor base from the [http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1522592](external corridor) set
  • a 2x2 [http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1484966](cut stone external wall tile)
  • a 2x0.5 doorway from this set.
  • a rounded door from this set.

my gut is that most hallways have doors that open out, so I position the doorway piece so that the hinge opens out.

Assembling a single door corridor Making a cut-stone 2 door corridor

To assemble a corridor with a door on both sides door, print:

  • A 2x2 cut stone external corridor base from the [http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1522592](external corridor) set
  • a 2x2 [http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1422779](cut stone floor tile)
  • Two 2x0.5 doorways from this set.
  • Two rounded doors from this set.
Assembling a double door corridor You can also just use a normal doorway tile with a wall tile to add a door for a corridor if you don't mind showing that there is at least some squares behind the door. Changelog
  • 7/27/2016 - Fixed all 4x tiles. They were missing the pin holes for the hinge.

author: TTB_Studios

description.text:
Updated- 01/11/12 gave a little more clearance and a little more chamfer to the fender.
The nice machined side of a bearing is much more accurate than any printed part we can currently produce, so I'd rather not print a guide that encases the bearing. Instead, you can use these chamfered fenders instead of fender washers. They (hopefully) don't interfere with the spin of the bearing, but will keep the belt on track. The only problem with them is that the fender won't spin, so if the belt rubs, it will cause some friction. it's probably a good idea to coat them with some grease.

These are designed to have a regular 8mm washer between the part and the bearing. Print 2 and put one on each side. you can use a fender washer if you'd like behind the printed part, or a regular washer.

I'm one of those people who is continually collecting tools and components for future (sometimes non-existing) projects. I'm also one of those people who likes to keep everything in a strict and even frightening (to others) order.

I was looking for a design that could help me protecting and organizing electronic components and small tools. As I could not find something online to solve this problem for me I decided to do something about it:

This system of interlocking and stackable modular boxes contains internal divisions of different sizes in order to organize a multitude of objects of different nature. Each level has a different internal distribution, on the top I added a lid and on the sides there are a series of hooks that click together and hold each level in position.

I used a 4mm plywood sheet to laser-cut every piece of the boxes, all three levels come out of a 80cm x 60cm sheet.

remixed_from.title: Leap Motion VR Mount - easier to print

title: Oculus Rift CV1 Leap Motion mount

description.text:
Super simple Leap Motion mount for the CV1 that prints quickly in one piece.

Holds the unique distinction of being fully functional (although a little structurally weak) if the print is stopped halfway through.

Postprocessing requires either a roll of electrical tape or a hot glue gun and a couple thumbscrews.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple White

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Once printed, you've got two options for getting the mount to stay on the rift: Either wrap the prongs in a few layers of electrical tape and rely on friction (I recommend this because it keeps the rift's fabric from getting scuffed) or insert a 3mm thumbscrew in each prong and cover the tips of the screw with a bead of glue from a hotglue gun (snugger fit, but slightly harder to remove).

comments.text:
Hi from belgium!
I bought the heated bed trough bq shop and i feel bad for having to pay so much. I thought they were gonna give me support and propper firmware to use the hephestos with a heated bed. All they did was direct me to this link http://www.mibqyyo.com/en-articles/2015/09/25/how-to-install-the-heatbed-on-your-prusa-i3-3d-printer/#/vanilla/discussion/embed/?vanilla_discussion_id=0 wich didn't help at all. I kept having problems with my stepper motor on the extruder after a few lines and the temperature fluctuated to much.Luckily i found your link here and... it works great! Is it possible to get the arduino files for this? Just a hint for other people you need to use an older version of cura to be able to put a custom firmware on your hephestos. 15.0.4.2 did the trick.

description.text: This is a Dual Titan Extruder system with all printable parts needed to upgrade the BigBox printer to a Dual Titan Extruder.

Printer:

E3D BigBox

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

35% and 100%

Notes:

I am reprinting this in ABS, it is cheaper than Edge, and I used all of the green, printing Rev 1.
I chose 35% for strength, you could probably do less.
Using V6 .4 nozzle will give good quality and accuracy.
Don't be afraid to use brim to help with warping.
First Layer
95% Height
100% Width
30% Speed
Print speed - 50mm/s
Along with all of the parts here, you will also need this need an extended nozzle wipe bracket here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1641748

Rev 1

Initial Release

Rev 2

Release Notes:

  1. Increase X Axis Rod Hole Diameter slightly for an easy fit.
  2. Moved the x-belt tensioner to allow for a cable trough for the left extruder.
  3. Added a cable trough for the cables of the right extruder
  4. Moved the x-axis end stop location, to accommodate x-belt tensioner move, on x-carriage and x-idler.
  5. Removed interlocking feature on rod clamp for x-axis idler and motor mount to assist in assembly, and installation of the x-axis drive assembly.
  6. Removed some material on the motor mount to allow for more +y movement. Rev 1 didn't have enough clearance, and would run into the Y-axis motor mount in the rear.
  7. Increased x-endstop wire routing size under x-carriage.
  8. Increased Titan Extruder height to allow for more range of motion for when using a Volcano Hotend and Regular V6 Hotend together. You may need to use 25mm long adjustment screws in the Titan Carriage.
  9. Increased fan shroud opening size near extruders to allow for more airflow. The openings now get increasing wider from front to back to help with more even airflow.
Rev 3

Release Notes:

  1. The X Carriage cable troughs for extruder wires have been updated to allow for more room.

  2. Fix Titan Extruder Carriage model to fit the Titan Extruder.
Update: June 16th 2016 @ 2:30am

Titan_Dual_X_Carriage_rev4
-Added fillets in cabling pathways
-Modified face by endstop, the endstop lever got stuck in rev3
-Made rear cable attachment posts thicker

Titan_Dual_X_Idler_rev3
-Added more material around x-axis rod clamps screws, they broke when printed in ABS 35% fill
-Fixed x-axis rod hole issue in rev2 (features got lost from rev 1 to rev 2)
-Made x-axis rod hole larger 8.35mm to help with smooth and easy rod movement for assembly into BigBox to prevent the need of removing the top acrylic supports.
-Changed belt attachment location back to original space of the BigBox so there is no need to modify the y axis drive belts.
-Modified model to allow for full 200mm movement in the y-axis, the X Idler was hitting the Y-Idler on the BigBox

Titan_Dual_Motor_Mount_rev3
Titan_Dual_X_Idler_rev3
-Added more material around x-axis rod clamps screws, they broke when printed in ABS 35% fill
-Fixed x-axis rod hole issue in rev2 (features got lost from rev 1 to rev 2)
-Made x-axis rod hole larger 8.35mm to help with smooth and easy rod movement for assembly into BigBox to prevent the need of removing the top acrylic supports.
-Changed belt attachment location back to original space of the BigBox so there is no need to modify the y axis drive belts.
-Modified model to allow for full 200mm movement in the y-axis, the X Motor Mount was hitting the Y-Idler on the BigBox

Titan_Dual_X_Carriage_rev4
-Added another slot for zip tieing cables (on the top of the part). Might be useful depending how you want to run your wires.

Update: June 16th 2016 @ 12:41pm

Titan_Dual_X_Carriage_rev5
-Added mounting location for IR Sensor Mount in rear of carriage

Titan_Dual_IR_Sensor_Mount_rev1
-Modified E3D v1.1 sensor mount to fit

Update: June 18th 2016 @ 11:08pm

Dual_Titan_Print_Fan_Shroud_rev3
-Changed design to a potentially more efficient filament cooling design for better cooling in more situations.
-Changed design to allow for better quality printing with no supports at the top of the shroud.

Update: June 20th 2016 @ 5:20pm

Dual_Titan_Print_Fan_Shroud_rev4
-Rotate nozzles to point to opposite side of nozzles to help with runaway airflow.
-added internal flow control to help with directional flow from the nozzles
-increased nozzle width to allow for more air.

Dual_Titan_X_Carriage_rev6
-Minor change to prevent the endstop from getting stuck in closed position.

Update June 22nd 2016 @ 6:15pm

Dual_Titan_Print_Fan_Shroud_rev5
-New and simpler design
-4 large nozzles should get complete coverage. There were too many losses with numerous small nozzles.
-Hopefully this works.

Update June 24nd 2016 @ 6:33pm

Dual_Titan_Print_Fan_Shroud_rev6
-Angled nozzles to direct air downward at nozzle tip
-Widened the nozzles slightly and increased height of nozzles to allow for more airflow.

I love the hexagon style and I wanted a Swiss Army styled key chain so I made this. I've got some more ideas for more features too, and I'll add them if I've got some time. The newest versions are available for free as in freedom and as in free beer on Github. Feel free to remix and commit.

Customize (optional)

If you want to make your own Sparky Swiss Army KeyChain you can even use the preconfigured STL-Files or customize the key chain in Customizer or OpenSCAD. You might also need some adapter rings (see AdapterRing.scad) if your keys have too big holes or don't want the keys to move around.

description.text: For easy printing I remake Hot-End Retainer.

These coins were made from this image here: http://img01.deviantart.net/b261/i/2013/180/6/1/selesnya_conclave_guild_symbol_by_drdraze-d6b7zgz.png

Use as tokens or to decorate your deckboxes for White-Green decks!

Enjoy!

For my final project, I wanted to create an optical illusion model that could be used by Dr. Przybyla, and other psychology professors, to demonstrate the effects of misperception. I chose to design an ames room, a distorted room that appears cubic when monocularly (with one eye), from a specific viewpoint, even though the room is actually trapezoidal. Additionally, objects in the room tend to appear as if shrinking or growing when moving from one corner to the other.

Here is an example of this effect demonstrated by infamous Dr. Philip Zimbardo:
https://youtu.be/hCV2Ba5wrcs
